text: Palace will have views: keep HMQ out of politics by making sure successor nominated by PM can command confidence of parliament. Still raw memories of how Queen perceived to have been unfairly drawn too close to politics when Tory ‘Magic Circle’ chose Alec Douglas-Home in 1963
author: nicholaswatt

text: ...if ERG or DUP kick off against Candidate X then PM could tell cabinet: I will not be able to advise the Queen that he / she can command confidence of parl. So some power still in hands of PM +  whichever group in governing party in hung parliament that decides to kick off.
author: nicholaswatt

text: ...these are not normal times. A candidate commanding the support of this cabinet may not be enough if a significant proportion of the governing party (ERG?) suggest they have no confidence in the cabinet’s candidate. So ERG and PM could both have cards to play...
author: nicholaswatt

text: When a PM resigns they are expected to protect the monarch from the political fray by advising which candidate is best placed to command the confidence of parliament. In normal times commanding the confidence of the cabinet shd do the trick. But...
author: nicholaswatt

text: EU source says problem with Theresa May’s performance was that their already rock bottom confidence in her ability to pass her deal in parliament declined even further
author: nicholaswatt

text: Theresa May’s less than assured performance at EU summit decisive in persuading EU leaders to put the “negative” track in their conclusions, EU source says. Negative track = UK out on 12 April if deal rejected next week + UK declines to take part in Euro parliamentary elections
author: nicholaswatt

text: PM sounding a bit less no-dealy tonight. Pivot or reaching out to Labour MPs she alienated last night?
author: nicholaswatt

text: PM: if we don’t get the deal through we have to work with the House of Commons. Very interesting: this came in answer to Q by @tnewtondunn asking if her deal falls would she advocate a longer extension or a softer Brexit if approved by parliament. Didn’t rule that out
author: nicholaswatt

text: PM: Clear choice. Deal with meaningful vote next week or come back to EU before 12 April with a plan. If further extension UK would have to stand candidates in European Parliamentary elections (which she opposes)
author: nicholaswatt

text: PM: I will make sure we make every effort to leave with a deal. A deal?
author: nicholaswatt

text: Lab source: position could evolve. Good discussions with supporters of Common Market 2.0 proposal = customs arrangement + membership of single market through EEA / EFTA pillar. “We believe there’s a majority in parl for an alternative to the PM’s botched and failed Brexit deal”
author: nicholaswatt

text: Labour source: under our plan the Northern Ireland backstop would fall away because UK would be in a new comprehensive customs union with EU and have close alignment with the single market
author: nicholaswatt

text: Labour source: party agrees with Theresa May that article 50 extension cannot go beyond 30 June. Delay should be used to amend (non legally binding) political declaration not the (legally binding) withdrawal agreement
author: nicholaswatt

text:
What a line up. Not just one star, not just two stars but three outstanding stars who will make Newsnight compelling viewing. Obviously there’s the annoying bit about even more homework to cope with their forensic questioning

@BBCNewsnight @maitlis @KirstyWark @Emmabarnett
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Theresa May opts for short extension to article 50...as opinion in EU hardens against a long extension

@BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Maybe speaker will allow votes today on alternative Brexit plans. Anna Soubry told Martha Kearney Alison McGovern to push for motion under Standing Order No 24. Speaker said on Monday: this procedure has teeth

⁦@Anna_Soubry⁩ ⁦@Alison_McGovern⁩ ⁦@BBCr4today⁩
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Blog: Opinion in EU hardening against long Brexit delay with 22 May emerging as definitive exit date with no further extension https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-47633879 …

@BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Breaking news on Brexiteer cabinet ministers meeting tonight to discuss tactics after PM failed to spell out clearly her position in cabinet on an article 50 extension
author: nicholaswatt

text: Also on @BBCNewsnight tonight: those close to Brexit talks in Whitehall believe the EU is hardening against a long extension to article 50. New definitive exit date being talked about is 22 May
author: nicholaswatt

text: In first tweet I meant to say what type of article 50 extension PM will seek
author: nicholaswatt

text: Am told there were residual concerns among Brexit ministers after this morning’s cabinet: Theresa May gave a flavour of her thinking on article 50 extension but no decision was made
author: nicholaswatt

text: On @BBCNewsnight tonight: Brexit cabinet ministers met tonight to discuss next steps after Theresa May failed to make decision in cabinet on what type of article 50 she will request
author: nicholaswatt

text: No 10 endorses Solicitor General Robert Buckland’s view that UK now in a political crisis. Spx: that has come to pass
author: nicholaswatt

text: Here is govt’s preferred option to challenge John Bercow: 1) Seal deal with DUP tomorrow. 2) Tell Brexiteer Tories: now or never. 3) If PM has a majority vote to reject precedent cited by speaker. 4) Hold 3rd meaningful vote. 5) Win + go to EU + request short article 50 extension
author: nicholaswatt

text: Solicitor general Robert Buckland tells me prorogation of parliament (creating a new session of parliament) is probably only way round John Bercow’s “binding” ruling. But he thinks prorogation unlikely
author: nicholaswatt

text: No 10: we were not given any notice of John Bercow’s statement
author: nicholaswatt

text: In December I wrote that John Bercow was so alarmed by the #Brexit deadlock he might make a decisive intervention. Well today was the day for that
author: nicholaswatt

text: Jacob Rees-Mogg to speaker: may I say how delighted I am that you have followed precedent
author: nicholaswatt

text: Bill Cash to speaker: what you say makes an enormous amount of sense
author: nicholaswatt

text: John Bercow: PM cannot put forward the same proposition
author: nicholaswatt

text: John Bercow blocks Theresa May from holding further “meaningful votes” on her #Brexit deal unless PM brings forward a new proposition
author: nicholaswatt

text: Looks like John Bercow has a long type written statement in his hands
author: nicholaswatt

text: SNP massively voted in favour of Lucy Powell amendment: 34 out of 35
author: nicholaswatt

text: There was confusion. They were meant to abstain. Some did some didn’t
author: nicholaswatt

text: The SNP abstained in the Powell vote
author: nicholaswatt

text: Brexiteer fury that cabinet ministers not sacked for abstaining in no deal vote. Former Tory chief whip Lord Blencathra says: “No one is so grand that they cannot be replaced but when the whipping and discipline system breaks down then that can never be recovered.”
author: nicholaswatt

text: Labour source: big govt loss. 17 Tory rebels
author: nicholaswatt

text: Word is Sarah Newton has resigned as a minister in the lobbies
author: nicholaswatt

text: Tories saying a number of ministers abstaining in final vote to reject government motion as amended by Spelman vote. ‘In normal times you would sacked for that.’ Tory tells me
author: nicholaswatt

text: Cabinet minister confirms: if government defeats its no deal motion as amended by Spelman vote, PM relieved of obligation to hold article 50 extension vote tomorrow
author: nicholaswatt

text: Govt now facing ministerial resignation alert. Govt planning to whip against their no deal motion because it has now been amended to rule out no deal in all circumstances. If govt whips against that ministers say they will resign
author: nicholaswatt

text: Word is narrow govt loss on Caroline Spelman amendment ruling out no deal in all circs
author: nicholaswatt

text:
No 10: owing to PM’s voice Michael Gove will open this afternoon’s no deal Brexit debate in commons. PM had wanted to open debate but decided not to after PMQs

@theresa_may @BBCNewsnight @michaelgove
author: nicholaswatt

text: Philip Hammond saying possible vote tomorrow on article 50 extension (and probably backbench amendments for other Brexit options) is a chance to find a consensus across the house. Not approach of Theresa May who believes her deal is the only viable deal
author: nicholaswatt

text: Suella Braverman declines to tell Emily Maitlis whether she has confidence in Theresa May @BBCNewsnight @maitlis @SuellaBraverman
author: nicholaswatt

text: Senior people in the cabinet, maybe the cabinet as a whole, should be having a conversation with Theresa May about her future Nicky Morgan tells Newsnight @BBCNewsnight @NickyMorgan01
author: nicholaswatt

text: The new Dromey / Spelman amendment says: “This house rejects the UK leaving the EU without a Withdrawal Agreement and a Framework for the Future Relationship.”
author: nicholaswatt

text: Leave minister says parliament will knock out Theresa May’s no deal motion, which keeps it as default position, and vote instead for amendment tabled by Jack Dromey and Caroline Spelman which rules out no deal altogether
author: nicholaswatt

text: Leave minister tells me: Brexit is over. No deal will be taken off the table tomorrow
author: nicholaswatt

text: PM: free vote on no deal vote tomorrow
author: nicholaswatt

text: Minister: I will do everything to stop no deal
author: nicholaswatt

text: Minister: it is dreadful. Significant numbers. We are in a very difficult position
author: nicholaswatt

text: Labour source: PM has lost big
author: nicholaswatt

text: Labour source: Well that trick whatever it was backfired... the lobby is *packed* with Tories
author: nicholaswatt

text: One Tory says after voting dressed in black tie: this is what they wore on the Titanic
author: nicholaswatt

text: DUP source: looks like vote against PM bigger than we thought this afternoon
author: nicholaswatt

text: Labour source: Tory vote against Theresa May looks massive in division lobbies
author: nicholaswatt

text: Only person I spotted emerging from Jubilee Room tonight who was also at that 1995 launch in addition to John Redwood was Norman Lamont
author: nicholaswatt

text: ERG source tells me: most of our group standing firm in rejecting deal. We have pulled some back. Clear that as we wait the deal gets better. So why not wait some more
author: nicholaswatt

text: John Redwood emerges from ERG meeting in Jubilee Room where he launched his 1995 leadership bid
author: nicholaswatt

text: Senior Brexit Tory tells me around 25 Tory MPs will switch to support PM + lots of abstentions. Not nearly enough for PM
author: nicholaswatt

text: Another switcher. Sir Robert Syms tells PM he will support her deal
author: nicholaswatt

text: Finally from DUP: The European Union has been intransigent. It is possible to reach a sensible deal which works for the United Kingdom and the European Union but it will require all sides to be reasonable and in deal making mode.
author: nicholaswatt

text: DUP adds: We want to see a deal which works for every part of the United Kingdom.  We will support the right deal which respects the referendum result and Northern Ireland’s place as an integral part of the United Kingdom.
author: nicholaswatt

text: Looking DUP unlikely to support PM. Spokesman: it is clear that the risks remain that the UK would be unable to lawfully exit the backstop were it to be activated
author: nicholaswatt

text: ERG source told me: if Jacob Rees-Mogg became PM he would pull UK out of withdrawal treaty
author: nicholaswatt

text: Geoffrey Cox to Jacob Rees-Mogg: UK has sovereign right to withdraw from this treaty. Would be unwise bc EU would introduce counter measures. ERG sources say commitment that UK can withdraw from treaty crucial to JRM as he decides how to vote
author: nicholaswatt

text: Chris Bryant challenges Geoffrey Cox claim that highly unlikely UK would be trapped in backstop by saying Cox told him three years ago that highly unlikely he would be made attorney general
author: nicholaswatt

text: Yes negotiations are at an end Geoffrey Cox tells Anna Soubry. Now we have to make a decision
author: nicholaswatt

text: I’m an old criminal.....barrister Anna Soubry tells Geoffrey Cox
author: nicholaswatt

text: Steve Baker: if we negotiate under this agreement we will either find ourselves trapped in backstop or we will have to agree to a customs union, contrary to our manifesto commitment. Sounds like a no
author: nicholaswatt

text: Michael Gove now makes it two Leave voting cabinet ministers on front bench for Geoffrey Cox statement
author: nicholaswatt

text: Nigel Dodds: from what AG is saying NI could be trapped
author: nicholaswatt

text: Sir Bill Cash: In the light of our own legal analysis and others we do not recommend accepting the Government’s motion today.
author: nicholaswatt

text: Sir Bill Cash ERG star chamber says no
author: nicholaswatt

text: Sir Bill Cash: the legal impediments trump political considerations. His view matters because Cash chairs the ERG star chamber of lawyers who will judge revised brexit deal. Includes DUP deputy leader Nigel Dodds
author: nicholaswatt

text: Sir Bill Cash: insufficient legal protection for NI. Sounds like a no
author: nicholaswatt

text: Interesting that only Leave voting cabinet minister currently on front bench for Geoffrey Cox statement is Steve Barclay
author: nicholaswatt

text: Finally Tory grandee tells me: it is my instinct that the DUP can support this deal. And they are the key
author: nicholaswatt

text: Grandee adds: problem was Geoffrey Cox letter landed so soon before meeting with PM. All the Brexiteers pounced on paragraph 19 which says risk of being trapped in backstop reduced. But seen in round letter makes clear there are substantive changes
author: nicholaswatt

text: Tory grandee tells me: meeting with PM went better than expected
author: nicholaswatt

text: Amber Rudd: tone of meeting with PM was thoughtful. We need to look at this politically not just legally. We will win tonight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Mark Francois: I regret to say I was unconvinced by PM’s answers
author: nicholaswatt

text: Mark Francois says mood of meeting with PM was polite. But question after question on Geoffrey Cox advice that changes only reduce risk of UK being caught in NI backstop
author: nicholaswatt

text: Finally from the Leave minister: it is all very sad because the legal advice says PM has secured changes and reduced risk of being trapped in NI backstop. Of course you can never have a cast iron guarantee on anything and legal advice reflects that reality
author: nicholaswatt

text: The Leave minister adds: if Brexit goes down it will be the fault of the hardline Brexiteers. But I don’t really care any more
author: nicholaswatt

text: Leave supporting minister tells me: I do not see how DUP can support PM’s brexit deal after Geoffrey Cox’s legal advice. Can’t see it passing without them
author: nicholaswatt

text: Geoffrey Cox ain’t no Peter Goldsmith, sung to the tune of Bill Withers Ain’t No Sunshine. Sort of scans if you take out Peter
author: nicholaswatt

text: Leading Brexiteer tells me: PM’s agreement with EU tonight just about looks OK. All down to Geoffrey Cox. If can provide robust legal advice that the UK can get out of the NI backstop then this should go through
author: nicholaswatt

text: Brexiteer Sir Mike Penning: I can now vote for the deal
author: nicholaswatt

text: Cabinet minister tells me on Theresa May’s #Brexit negotiations in Strasbourg: It’s not looking good
author: nicholaswatt

text: Brexit minister Robin Walker: meaningful vote will take place on Tuesday with MPs fully informed on government legal advice
author: nicholaswatt

text: Brexit minister Robin Walker says attorney general will update his brexit legal advice
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Liam Fox: I fear Brexit may never happen

@LiamFox @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Blog: Brexiteer concerns over conflicting roles of “Pooh-Bah” attorney general Geoffrey Cox. He is leading negotiations with EU on NI backstop but will then mark his own homework by deciding whether to change legal advice https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-47409659 …

@Geoffrey_Cox @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Supporter of Cooper / Letwin amendment tells me: we have won this round because Theresa May has taken on board substance of our amendment. Sometimes when you win it can take a bit to absorb that. Supporters meeting this afternoon to decide next steps
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Blog: lonely PM reaches out after Tory defections. Phillip Lee has not spoken to PM since he resigned as a minister. Then in space of 24 hours texts from party chairman, chief whip + 45 min meeting with PM

@DrPhillipLeeMP @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Anna Soubry endorses George Osborne’s chancellorship, thereby endorsing his welfare cuts - in answer to Gary Gibbon question. Tricky for the Gang of Seven ex Labour MPs watching on

@TheIndGroup @GaryGibbonBlog @Anna_Soubry
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Interesting that Anna Soubry has called on Liberal Democrat MPs to join the Independent Group. So as a former SDP supporter she obviously wants to avoid the problems of the old SDP / Liberal Alliance

@Anna_Soubry @LibDems @TheIndGroup
author: nicholaswatt

text: Anna Soubry: it is with a heavy heart that I leave the Conservative party
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Sarah Wollaston: it is with great sadness that I leave the Conservative party. I would not have stood for Conservative party in 2010 if it was then as it is now

@sarahwollaston
author: nicholaswatt

text: Strikingly different atmosphere at the Anna Soubry, Sarah Wollaston, Heidi Allen press conference compared with the Gang of Seven on Monday. Today the trio are smiling and look happy to have defected from Tories. The Gang of Seven looked really sad to have left Labour
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Ironic for Heidi Allen, Anna Soubry and Sarah Wollaston. They are now making polite conversation in the Commons chamber with the DUP, having told Theresa May they are defecting because she is too close to them

@Anna_Soubry @sarahwollaston @Heidi_LDN
author: nicholaswatt

text: Tory minister who is a Brexit supporter: ‘genuinely saddened by departure of Anna Soubry. She is a real Conservative. Not bothered by Sarah Wollaston and Heidi Allen. They are not proper Conservatives - they were selected as candidates in open processes’
author: nicholaswatt

text: And that is precisely what Sinn Fein did. They did everything at Westminster short of taking their seats. Indeed a few years later I remember interviewing Gerry Adams for the Guardian in his centrally located Westminster office above St Stephen’s entrance
author: nicholaswatt

text: I am fully aware of the history of abstentionism from my time as the Times Ireland Correspondent over 20 years ago. I remember having a big row with Sinn Fein in the run up to the 1997 election when I said they would pursue a policy of active abstentionism
author: nicholaswatt

text: I was not saying Sinn Fein will take their seats or should take their seats. Simply reporting on what others have said and may say again
author: nicholaswatt

text: OK. Time to get grumpy with Ben and others who took issue with my Sinn Fein abstentionism tweet. I was saying that the Taoiseach might say again what he and others in the Dail have been saying: Sinn Fein should take their seats at Westminster
author: nicholaswatt

text: So defections are on
author: nicholaswatt

text: Word is new defections set for 11am
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Senior Liberal Democrat told me they would reach a cooperation agreement with the Independent Group. Senior IG source told me they want to keep their distance from the Lib Dems. ‘There is no way we are joining the Lib Dems. No way,’ source told me

@TheIndGroup @LibDems
author: nicholaswatt

text: A big test for them. If you sit as an opposition MP and you don’t vote against the PM in a no confidence vote are you an opposition MP?
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Sinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald told Andrew Marr Sinn Fein would not take its seats for the obvious historical reasons around abstention. But she also said her seven MPs would not make a difference at Westminster. That second argument now open to challenge

@MaryLouMcDonald
author: nicholaswatt

text: The new tighter numbers in parliament could be used by Leo Varadkar who has been telling Sinn Fein they should take their seats when future of Ireland at stake. If SF did so and the three Tory defectors voted with the opposition Theresa May could lose a no confidence notion
author: nicholaswatt

text: The defection of three Tories would make the numbers even tighter in parliament for Theresa May. With the DUP she would have the support of 324 MPs. You need 322 to command a majority, counting out the speaker and seven Sinn Fein MPs
author: nicholaswatt

text: The defection of three Tory MPs would be symbolically far more significant than defection of eight Labour MPs. They would be crossing the floor of the Commons to sit on opposition benches
author: nicholaswatt

text: Tory whips had assumed Anna Soubry would jump ship when new group was established on Monday. Suspicions grew that afternoon when she failed to vote in three Commons votes even though she was neither slipped nor paired. Tory whips saying the three have gone ‘very very silent’
author: nicholaswatt

text: A source in The Independent Group told me last night of possible defection of the three Tories: I can neither confirm nor deny. But tomorrow [Wednesday] will be a busy day
author: nicholaswatt

text:
I reported last night on Newsnight: strong rumours that Sarah Woolaston, Anna Soubry and Heidi Allen would defect to the Independent Group this morning. Looking like it may happen shortly before PMQs

@Anna_Soubry @sarahwollaston @heidiallen75 @BBCNewsnight @TheIndGroup
author: nicholaswatt

text: The Gang of Seven sent coordinated emails resigning from the Labour party from press conference venue minutes before going public
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Source in The Independent Group: fundamental problem with Jeremy Corbyn’s leadership = Marxism masquerading as the Labour party

@TheIndGroup @jeremycorbyn @UKLabour
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Tony Blair’s office tells Newsnight: Tony Blair knew nothing about today’s events

@BBCNewsnight #theindependentgroup
author: nicholaswatt

text: Stern look on the faces of the Gang of Seven. Unlike smiles when Gang of Four launched the precursor to the SDP in Limehouse Declaration in January 1981
author: nicholaswatt

text: Luciana Berger: a painful and difficult decision to resign from the Labour party
author: nicholaswatt

text: And it’s not the Gang of Four, it’s the Gang of Seven: @ChukaUmunna @gavinshuker Anne Coffey Angela Smith @ChrisLeslieMP @lucianaberger @MikeGapes #notthesdp #theindependentgroup
author: nicholaswatt

text: Awaiting the Limehouse - sorry - the Westminster Bridge Declaration at County Hall #notthesdp
author: nicholaswatt

text: If this weather continues the coat / scarf combo can end
author: nicholaswatt

text: Great to have been released from the incredibly strict dress code enforced by the Guardian
author: nicholaswatt

text: Very significant scoop by @anguswalkertalk.  PM’s chief brexit negotiator Olly Robbins overheard discussing: 1) Article 50 extension when No 10 denying that is on PM’s mind; 2) How NI backstop with a customs union was meant as bridge to future relationship when PM says no to CU
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Blog: Theresa May wants us to believe she is serious about embracing no-deal because she sees it as an important negotiating card. But that is not necessarily the same as wanting it to happen https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-47219791 …

@BBCNewsnight @theresa_may
author: nicholaswatt

text: On Newsnight Fianna Fáil leader Micheal Martin tells me Donald Tusk’s remarks on Brexiteers were not helpful. He said they did nothing to advance a resolution to #Brexit. He called for calm engagement because the stakes are so high @MichealMartinTD @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Anyone surprised by the strength of Donald Tusk’s language should see his interview for Norma Percy’s @BBCTwo documentary on UK and EU. He said he told David Cameron that the Brexit referendum was stupid
author: nicholaswatt

text: Hooray for my great friend and outstanding journalist colleague @BethRigby
author: nicholaswatt

text: Jeremy Corbyn: I look forward to meeting Theresa May to discuss Brexit.
author: nicholaswatt

text: Cabinet minister on Graham Brady win: good for PM who can finally tell the EU what Parliament supports. About as good as you could hope for
author: nicholaswatt

text: Graham Brady amendment passes by 16
author: nicholaswatt

text: MPs now voting on Sir Graham Brady amendment
author: nicholaswatt

text: So Parliament now officially opposed to no deal Brexit. PM will say that weakens her hand with EU. But any amendment passed tonight is not legally binding
author: nicholaswatt

text: Caroline Spelman wins by 8
author: nicholaswatt

text: Labour source: 5 Labour MPs voting against Spelman
author: nicholaswatt

text: Labour source: Spelman amendment could go through. 17 Tories voting for it. Says it will be close
author: nicholaswatt

text: Tory source on Spelman: it will be close. Govt could lose
author: nicholaswatt

text: Cabinet minister ditty sung to tune of Lord of the Dance hymn
author: nicholaswatt

text: Cabinet minister: vote vote wherever you may be. Vote vote vote with the DUP
author: nicholaswatt

text: Rachel Reeves loses by 32. Now voting on Caroline Spelman amendment
author: nicholaswatt

text: Rachel Reeves amendment would have obliged PM to delay article 50 by two years if no deal by 26 February
author: nicholaswatt

text: Labour source: Rachel Reeves amendment lost
author: nicholaswatt

text: Labour source who predicted Yvette Cooper defeat predicts Caroline Spelman amendment will pass because: Labour MPs who voted against Cooper will switch. Spelman amendment simply rules out no deal. But massive Tory whips operation to defeat Spelman
author: nicholaswatt

text: Yvette Cooper loses by 23, slightly higher than Dominic Grieve defeat. Around a dozen Labour MPs defying whip over fears of prolonging Brexit deadline
author: nicholaswatt

text: Two Labour sources: Yvette Cooper amendment won’t go through
author: nicholaswatt

text: Labour source: expect Yvette Cooper amendment to be defeated by higher margin than Dominic Grieve one. More Labour MPs voting against or abstaining
author: nicholaswatt

text: And Dominic Grieve amendment defeated. Not good for Yvette Cooper amendment
author: nicholaswatt

text: Labour source: not looking good for Dominic Grieve amendment
author: nicholaswatt

text: Mark Francois, seen as one of ERG members most hostile to PM deal, says he will vote for Graham Brady amendment
author: nicholaswatt

text: Jacob Rees-Mogg: most important announcement by Theresa May today was commitment to reopen Withdrawal Agreement
author: nicholaswatt

text: Jacob Rees-Mogg: decision today does not commit us to supporting PM in two weeks if no changes to deal
author: nicholaswatt

text: Jacob Rees-Mogg: we will be supporting Graham Brady amendment bc of PM commitments
author: nicholaswatt

text: Senior Tory MP leaving ERG meeting: most will support Graham Brady amendment
author: nicholaswatt

text: Boris Johnson tells ERG meeting: give the PM one last chance. We can come back in two weeks time. So looks like conditional support from BoJo for Graham Brady amendment tonight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Looks like strong brexiteer European Research Group support for Graham Brady amendment to give Theresa May two more weeks to remove Northern Ireland backstop. Andrew Rosindell says they will vote against PM in two weeks if no change to deal
author: nicholaswatt

text: There is no better time to advance this alternative given the confusion and disarray which is now manifesting itself in Brussels.  This has been displayed both by the contradictory EU statements and the panic stricken behaviour of the Irish government.
author: nicholaswatt

text: If the Prime Minister is seeking to find a united front, both between elements in her own party and the DUP, in the negotiations which she will enter with the European Union, then this is a proposition which she should not turn her back on.
author: nicholaswatt

text: Arlene Foster: It also gives a feasible alternative to the backstop proposed by the European Union which would split the United Kingdom or keep the entire United Kingdom in the Customs Union and Single Market.
author: nicholaswatt

text: Arlene Foster: The DUP has given its endorsement to the plan.  We believe it can unify a number of strands in the Brexit debate including the views of remainers and leavers.
author: nicholaswatt

text: So the DUP have endorsed the Malthouse brexit plan
author: nicholaswatt

text: PM told Boris Johnson we won’t know unless you support us when he asked whether her idea would lead to change. Described as most sparky change
author: nicholaswatt

text: Tory MP at 1922 committee: PM said she will whip her party to support Graham Brady amendment to replace NI backstop. That prompted Andrew Murrison and John Baron to drop their NI backstop amendments
author: nicholaswatt

text: Blog: is Jacob Rees-Mogg ready to compromise on #brexit? https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-47033629 … @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: My interview with Andrea Leadsom in which she talks about how early intervention can transform a baby’s life chances @andrealeadsom
author: nicholaswatt

text: How exciting! One of the greatest commentators at Westminster
author: nicholaswatt

text: PM strategy is to show the EU how her deal could be passed in parliament with the message: you are saying no to amending the Northern Ireland backstop now. But here is how we pass my deal 4/
author: nicholaswatt

text:
One Tory Brexiteer tells me: with the DUP on board 80% of Tory Brexiteers would support Theresa May’s deal including Jacob Rees-Mogg. ‘If that happens you would be left with the mad and the bad on the two extremes’ 3/

@BBCNewsnight @Jacob_Rees_Mogg @duponline @theresa_may
author: nicholaswatt

text: One cabinet minister has told the DUP their votes are super-charged. Bring them on board and Theresa May secures extra 60 to 70 votes. DUP reckon they can bring over 110 extra votes - ten DUP + 100 from Conservatives and some Labour 2/
author: nicholaswatt

text: DUP sources tell me party willing to back Theresa May’s #Brexit deal if they get a cast iron legal guarantee that the Northern Ireland backstop would have a time limit 1/
author: nicholaswatt

text: Turns out @hilarybennmp has acknowledged that the wordsmith + Oxford don to the brains of Westminster @StewartWood was author of the door open / mind closed soundbite
author: nicholaswatt

text: Peace and harmony in the Labour Party? Jeremy Corbyn pinches Hilary Benn’s Theresa May #brexit soundbite to me last week - her door is open but her mind is closed
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Blog: Feeling in No 10 that PM buffeted by two forces: an EU which senses that Parliament might eventually take over; and a Parliament which looks increasingly likely to snatch decisive powers from the government https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-46951202 …

@theresa_may @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Interesting that Jeremy Corbyn, who would instinctively refer to Northern Ireland’s Maiden City as Derry, resorts to aristocratic pronounciation: Londond’ry
author: nicholaswatt

text: DUP source: The majority is exactly the DUP’s vote. If our ten switched then she’d have lost by 1
author: nicholaswatt

text: DUP: PM would have lost by one vote without our ten votes
author: nicholaswatt

text: SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford to PM: put extension of article 50 and second referendum on table in #brexit talks
author: nicholaswatt

text: Jeremy Corbyn challenge to PM: no serious #brexit talks unless you rule out no deal
author: nicholaswatt

text: So Theresa May finally invites Jeremy Corbyn to meet her...on brexit
author: nicholaswatt

text: The AG confirmed that during the NI backstop Great Britain would be in a customs union with the EU: “GB is in a separate customs union with the EU creating a single customs territory between the EU and the UK, meaning NI and GB are not in separate customs territories” /ends
author: nicholaswatt

text: In his legal advice on the Northern Ireland backstop the attorney general confirmed NI would be in the customs union: “NI remains in the EU’s Customs Union” /
author: nicholaswatt

text: In his #brexit legal advice the attorney general Geoffrey Cox confirmed that in the Northern Ireland backstop different parts of UK would be in both a + the customs union /
author: nicholaswatt

text:
When Theresa May (currently) rules out UK membership of a customs union with the EU in end relationship it is worth remembering she has already breached a key red line here: that the UK would neither be in a, or the, customs union /

@theresa_may @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: And finally. If PM needs to cut a deal with Jeremy Corbyn he may demand a high price: Labour votes for withdrawal agreement in exchange for Tory votes for general election to decide who negotiates UK’s future relationship with EU, as I wrote in November /
author: nicholaswatt

text: As Deep Throat didn’t say: follow the customs union though it may go by a different name 9/
author: nicholaswatt

text: PM L’ House:... I have an open mind on how we do it. It is not the means that matter, but the ends  8/
author: nicholaswatt

text: PM L’ House: I do want us to have a customs agreement with the EU. Whether that means we must reach a completely new customs agreement, become an associate member of the Customs Union in some way, or remain a signatory to some elements of it, I hold no preconceived position.../7
author: nicholaswatt

text: But in Lancaster House speech, regarded by Brexiteer Tories as the sacred text, PM was flexible on customs relationship with EU 6/
author: nicholaswatt

text: Theresa May currently saying no to customs union because her red lines include ability of UK to have independent trade policy 5/
author: nicholaswatt

text: So, in absence of a U-Turn by EU, only way for Theresa May to win is if Conservative + Labour frontbenches reach agreement. That means negotiations with Jeremy Corbyn who will put customs union on table 4/
author: nicholaswatt

text: Tricky bit: highly unlikely 130 Labour MPs will defy Jeremy Corbyn and support a #Brexit deal solely proposed by Theresa May even if she offers major concessions on workers rights 3/
author: nicholaswatt

text: At same time try to talk to Labour MPs in Leave-voting seats who need Brexit with a Labour-friendly face. If 130 of them come over PM can win without EU move on NI backstop 2/
author: nicholaswatt

text: As Theresa May ends her speech in no confidence vote here is her twin track #Brexit strategy: talk to DUP (want scrapping of NI backstop or UK exit mechanism) in hope EU will listen and embark on U-Turn 1/
author: nicholaswatt

text: ERG source tells me: we have done much better than I thought after word that 202 voted for govt
author: nicholaswatt

text: Word is govt has 202 votes
author: nicholaswatt

text: John Baron only manages 24 votes. One critic says: he tabled his amendment to make Theresa May’s defeat look rather better
author: nicholaswatt

text: Geoffrey Cox just highlighted main Tory criticism of him: he has poor feel for House of Commons because was so busy as a barrister before he became an MP. Just turned down an intervention by Sir Edward Leigh, a Brexiteer who has an amendment and is minded to support govt
author: nicholaswatt

text: Strong Geoffrey Cox warning about dangers of no deal, following Theresa May warnings yesterday that it could lead to break up of UK: sounds like big cabinet moves away from entertaining no deal if PM deal rejected
author: nicholaswatt

text: Geoffrey Cox: height of irresponsibility to contemplate no deal...We are playing here with people’s lives.
author: nicholaswatt

text: My interview tonight with @eastantrimmp Sammy Wilson for @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: No surprise as Theresa May enters 1922 committee. Yes. They are banging the desks and cheering
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Blog. Has Theresa May failed to understand the DUP? https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-46868541 …

@theresa_may @duponline @NigelDoddsDUP @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Nigel Dodds adds: We would rely on the Dublin government to speak up for us. Instead of meaningless letters, the Prime Minister should now ask for and deliver changes to the Withdrawal Agreement.

@NigelDoddsDUP @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Those Nigel Dodds concerns: 1) everything Attorney General said in his legal advice regarding the backstop still stands; 2) there has been no change to the Withdrawal Agreement; 3) NI would be subject to EU laws with no representation in Brussels

@NigelDoddsDUP @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text:
It appears that Theresa May’s exchange of letters with EU have not only failed to reassure the DUP. They may have unsettled the party even more. Nigel Dodds: rather than reassure us the Tusk and Juncker letter bolsters our concerns

@NigelDoddsDUP @theresa_may @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: So Theresa May’s exchange of letters with EU show she has failed to secure DUP demands on NI backstop. They are: 1) scrap it; or 2) secure an end date; or 3) secure a unilateral withdrawal mechanism. Key PM claim after winning vote of confidence: we have to win back @duponline
author: nicholaswatt

text: Here Donald Tusk and Jean-Claude Juncker repeat Dec message: no change to withdrawal agreement + no clarification that would undermine it. But happy to: 1) make clear they want to avoid NI backstop or at least for it to be temporary. 2) Move quickly to future relationship talks
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Biggest set back for Theresa May in exchange of letters with EU: PM indicates here that a unilateral UK exit mechanism from NI backstop or hard time limit would be transformative. EU response: no change to withdrawal agreement 
⁦@theresa_may⁩ ⁦@donaldtusk⁩
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Amber Rudd tells me: I would like to play a bodyguard in any sequel to The Bodyguard

@AmberRuddHR @Misskeeleyhawes #Bodyguard @_richardmadden @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Exclusive: Amber Rudd backs tax cuts for low paid workers, potentially costing more than £1bn https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-46845761 …

@AmberRuddHR @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Irish Tánaiste Simon Coveney tells Mark Carruthers of BBC Northern Ireland that Tory grandee quoted in my blog was ill informed and patronising https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-46528952 …

@simoncoveney @MarkCarruthers7 @BBCNewsnight @bbctheview
author: nicholaswatt

text: Hugo Swire admits to me that his amendment could not override the withdrawal agreement. But he says that, if passed, Theresa May could use it show what parliament needs to approve her #brexit deal
author: nicholaswatt

text: Jacob Rees Mogg tells me the Swire amendment not good enough because it would be trumped by the withdrawal agreement
author: nicholaswatt

text: Govt member to me on Dominic Grieve win: This is the death knell of the Blair control of parliament. We are watching the British constitution being shaped around us. In a hung parliament anything can happen
author: nicholaswatt

text: Nicky Morgan believes Dominic Grieve win important because she calculates that Theresa May could originally have waited until 14 February to report back if she loses next Tuesday. Now has to report back within three days
author: nicholaswatt

text: Dominic Grieve wins. Nicky Morgan: this is parliament taking back control. We want to stop Theresa May running down the clock on #brexit @NickyMorgan01 @theresa_may
author: nicholaswatt

text: Another Tory MP: we can’t get rid of the speaker. The only danger to him is whether he damages his reputation if people accept our view he is conspiring with Remainers to block Brexit
author: nicholaswatt

text: Tory MP to me: Bercow is just signing his death warrant
author: nicholaswatt

text: Clearly John Bercow is relishing confrontation with government and Tory critics. The smile on his face shows he has been waiting and preparing for this moment, the most significant of his speakership and perhaps of any modern speakership
author: nicholaswatt

text: Theresa May just left the commons chamber without acknowledging John Bercow as she walked past him
author: nicholaswatt

text: Which Brenda? Bristol one or Private Eye one?
author: nicholaswatt

text: Theresa May’s big announcement before #brexit debate: MPs will vote on whether to extend transition or go into NI backstop if no future UK / EU relationship in place by Dec 2020. Translation: parliament can exercise rights enshrined in withdrawal agreement. So no change to that
author: nicholaswatt

text:
John Bercow’s decision to accept the Dominic Grieve amendment is the long awaited decisive #brexit intervention by the commons speaker. Here is my blog from last month on how he was waiting for his moment https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-46593750 …

@BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Fascinating film by my great colleague @caithanrahan
author: nicholaswatt

text: Tory MP on Theresa May performance at anti no deal meeting: it was so sad just to watch her lose the room
author: nicholaswatt

text: So now we know: there is an anti no deal majority in parliament. Govt will be pleased majority small. But if there is a vote to prevent an actual no deal my interview with Richard Harrington confirms there will be ministerial resignations so numbers will increase
author: nicholaswatt

text: One Labour MP on Theresa May performance at anti no deal meeting: Jean-Claude Juncker was being polite when he said nebulous @theresa_may @JunckerEU
author: nicholaswatt

text: Labour MP says Theresa May told anti no deal meeting: only way to prevent no deal is to support a deal. Evidently she didn’t say her deal
author: nicholaswatt

text: One Labour MP attending anti no deal meeting with Theresa May:  it was a tour of the impact of no deal across the country as MPs spoke of the impact on their constituencies
author: nicholaswatt

text: Ben Bradshaw on anti no deal meeting convened by Caroline Spelman and Jack Dromey: this is a futile effort by PM to build consensus behind her #brexit deal. It is all too little too late
author: nicholaswatt

text: More from Ben Bradshaw on Theresa May: she was heard in silence with no applause
author: nicholaswatt

text: Ben Bradshaw on meeting with Theresa May to discuss need to avoid no deal. It is same old desperate platitudes from Theresa May. It was Maybot Mark Ten
author: nicholaswatt

text: Cabinet source says most of #brexit discussions in cabinet on no deal planning. Immediately after cabinet business secretary Greg Clark went to commons and said no deal should not be contemplated
author: nicholaswatt

text: Amber Rudd then said: “More than ever we need to find the centre, reach across the House and find a majority for what will be agreed. Anything will need legislation. I want us to proceed with Brexit, I want to find the will of the House.”
author: nicholaswatt

text: Amber Rudd then told cabinet no deal would make UK less safe after Sajid Javid reportedly said UK wouldn’t be able to uphold Dublin agreement and send people back
author: nicholaswatt

text: Sounds like a lively cabinet. Amber Rudd said: “History will take a dim view of a Cabinet that presses ahead with No Deal. We have to face world in which we find it, not as we wish it to be and we have to deal with the facts as we find them.”
author: nicholaswatt

text: Coming up on @BBCNewsnight: my encounter with @BorisJohnson on cheese and onion crisps and #brexit
author: nicholaswatt

text: Business minister Richard Harrington tells me after No 10 #brexit drinks he will “definitely” resign if that is needed to stop no deal. But he is confident party will support PM deal
author: nicholaswatt

text: Not just Tory MPs meeting Theresa May for #brexit drinks in No 10. DUP’s Nigel Dodds and Sammy Wilson just turned up with Owen Paterson. Sammy Wilson tells me: we have grave reservations about PM’s deal @NigelDoddsDUP @eastantrimmp @OwenPaterson
author: nicholaswatt

text: Tory MPs piling into No 10 for #brexit drinks with Theresa May. Boris Johnson tells me he hopes PM will listen to him @theresa_may @BorisJohnson
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Great news Ben! Look forward to welcoming you

@BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Blog: Theresa May cautiously hopeful that EU will help her on eve of #Brexit parliamentary vote. But differences may prove unbridgeable https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-46784840 …

@theresa_may @JunckerEU @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Word reaching me that immigration white paper will be published tomorrow
author: nicholaswatt

text: Parliament has adjourned for the night with no sign of the no confidence motion in the government, rather than just Theresa May, threatened by chief whip Nick Brown
author: nicholaswatt

text: The wording of a no confidence motion under Fixed Term Parliament: ‘That this House has no confidence in Her Majesty’s Government.’ Use that wording and terms of act triggered. Don’t use that wording like using wrong PIN code. So if Lab loses vote = failed to secure an election
author: nicholaswatt

text: So govt essentially challenging Jeremy Corbyn to carry out threat outlined by his chief whip Nick Brown: escalate to no confidence motion in govt under terms of Fixed Term Parliaments Act. If that fails then Labour policy: consider second referendum which leadership not keen on
author: nicholaswatt

text: I understand government will not allocate time for Jeremy Corbyn motion of no confidence in Theresa May. ‘We are not playing silly games’. If Labour escalate to no confidence motion in govt then time woild be allocated because that would come under Fixed Term Parliaments Act
author: nicholaswatt

text: Cath Haddon is the guru on all matters relating to no confidence motions
author: nicholaswatt

text: Am told Labour chief whip Nick Brown told PLP if the government doesn’t grant time for Jeremy Corbyn’s no confidence motion in Theresa May then Labour will escalate: no confidence motion in government as a whole under Fixed Term Parliaments Act. That has to be granted time
author: nicholaswatt

text: Theresa May likes suggestion by Sir Michael Fallon that start date of future trade relationship should be as certain as the paying over of the £39bn divorce settlement
author: nicholaswatt

text:
And now from across the chamber Yvette Cooper joins Andrew Mitchell in calling on Theresa May to request an extension of article 50

@YvetteCooperMP @theresa_may
author: nicholaswatt

text:
In this blog I explain why Jeremy Corbyn reluctant to table no confidence motion in Theresa May or government. Losing such a vote would trigger official Labour policy to consider second referendum of which he is wary

@jeremycorbyn @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Big boos on @Conservatives benches as former chief whip Andrew Mitchell calls on @theresa_may to extend article 50 rather than face new deal. Probably most senior Tory to float that
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Blog: how John Bercow could soon become one of the most powerful people in the land https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-46593750 …

@HouseofCommons #brexit @theresa_may @jeremycorbyn
author: nicholaswatt

text: Yea. Not as if he can recite Racine plays off by heart
author: nicholaswatt

text:
On a possible further EU referendum one Theresa May ally told me in September: “Maybe a second referendum is the last card we play to avoid a general election.”

@theresa_may @peoplesvote_uk @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Too kind!
author: nicholaswatt

text: I fear disappointment
author: nicholaswatt

text:
There’s a bloke here who has beautiful French. As for the other one....

@EUCouncil @EmmanuelMacron @Elysee
author: nicholaswatt

text: Biting. Donald Tusk: we have treated Theresa May with more respect than many MPs @theresa_may @donaldtusk
author: nicholaswatt

text:
The scathing assessment of UK tactics by senior EU figure was balanced by high praise for Theresa May: That was Theresa May’s best ever performance at any European Council

@theresa_may @BBCNewsnight @EUCouncil
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Disclosure that Theresa May reportedly suggested starting future relationship with EU in December 2021 indicates that she would like to extend the transition period until then - six months before 2022 general election

@theresa_may @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Senior EU figure: Brussels gave Theresa May everything she wanted because she tabled no legal demands. Suggested UK government has not read withdrawal agreement because Theresa May indicated she would like future relationship to start in Dec 2021 when agreed text says Dec 2020
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Senior EU figure adds: we reached out to Theresa May by making clear Northern Ireland backstop, if triggered, would be temporary and EU would use “best endeavours” to negotiate a future agreement with UK “expeditiously”

@BBCNewsnight @EUCouncil
author: nicholaswatt

text: View in Brussels: EU gave Theresa May “everything she wanted” today. This resulted in the EU “front-loading” the next stage if UK ratifies withdrawal agreement: preparations for future trading relationship immediately so they could start as soon as possible after Brexit
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Stark assessment from senior EU figure on #Brexit who tells me: The negotiations have ended. We are not talking to the British

@theresa_may @BBCNewsnight @EUCouncil
author: nicholaswatt

text:
And here is my interview with Austrian chancellor Sebastian Kurz

@sebastiankurz @theresa_may @EUCouncil
author: nicholaswatt

text:
My interview with Dutch PM Mark Rutte in which he criticises Labout MPs for laughing at Theresa May and expresses admiration for her

@theresa_may @EUCouncil @UKLabour
author: nicholaswatt

text: PM will say a win is a win but more than a third of her colleagues do not want her to be PM
author: nicholaswatt

text: Some in ERG were saying they expected 80 to vote against PM so they will say higher than expected. Others had forecast 120
author: nicholaswatt

text: PM wins 200 to 117
author: nicholaswatt

text: And the applause is prolonged
author: nicholaswatt

text: Big cheers and table banging at Theresa May win
author: nicholaswatt

text: Graham Brady: PM has won confidence vote
author: nicholaswatt

text: Here they come
author: nicholaswatt

text: And here comes Theresa May’s oldest friend in parliament Damian Green
author: nicholaswatt

text: But chief whip has big bags under his eyes
author: nicholaswatt

text: Chief whip Julian Smith has arrived in committee room 14 for result. He is smiling
author: nicholaswatt

text: Jacob Rees-Mogg: given the time I might go and celebrate Mass and then return and vote later
author: nicholaswatt

text:
James Cleverly says Theresa May will throw big effort into winning back DUP support for her #brexit deal. Given Sammy Wilson told me the DUP is determined to kill her deal that might be quite a challenge

@eastantrimmp @duponline @theresa_may @JamesCleverly
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Brexiteer: if that speech decided the vote Theresa May would lose. It was Maybot. But got to hand it to her: she made it here. I would have crumbled by now

@BBCNewsnight @theresa_may
author: nicholaswatt

text:
One old ally of Theresa May tells me: I think it will be fine. But her speech to the 1922 committee was not her best. Naturally she was nervous

@BBCNewsnight @theresa_may
author: nicholaswatt

text: PM ruling out leading party into next general election related to next scheduled one in 2022. Not related to earlier one but she has ruled out a snap election
author: nicholaswatt

text: Theresa May intimated to 1922 that she will not lead Conservatives into next election if she wins tonight. James Cleverly, party deputy chairman, says PM’s focus on delivering Brexit. But PM recognises where people are frustrated
author: nicholaswatt

text: .... whilst in the EU, the PM and senior Ministers several times appeared to be backsliding on clear commitments as soon as they saw draft legal texts giving effect to agreements they had struck.
author: nicholaswatt

text: Ivan Rogers adds on NI backstop: There was no other endgame from that point..But we got sophistry, evasions, euphemisms + sometimes straight denials at home....
author: nicholaswatt

text: Back to the Ivan Rogers lecture in Liverpool. On the Northern Ireland backstop, where PM seeking assurances, he says: It was obvious, reading the December 2017 Agreement document from outside Government that this must lead inexorably to where we have now reached.
author: nicholaswatt

text:
We always report this but in the circumstances potentially quite significant for Theresa May. Prolonged banging of desks as she entered 1922 committee

@BBCNewsnight @theresa_may
author: nicholaswatt

text: As PM makes pitch her former ambasador to EU, Ivan Rogers, says she is unlikely to get much joy in Brussels if she wins vote. ‘The EU is always very adroit at such exercises in solemnly reframing things which have already been agreed in ways that make the medicine slip down.’
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Increasing number of Brexiteers tell me they expect Theresa May to win confidence vote tonight. Even if she wins by wide margin they say her authority is shot to pieces and battle not over

@BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Member of the cabinet tells me: clear signals in private from Theresa May that she will not lead the Conservative party into the next general election. Minister not sure how clear she will make that publicly

 @BBCNewsnight @theresa_may
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Blog on Tory confidence vote: why every minute counts for Theresa May https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-46542152 …

@theresa_may @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Modernising Tory project is rocking. Around 100 Tory MPs expected to hear result of confidence vote tonight in Mayfair at Northern Powerhouse reception to be held at Jack Barclay Bentley dealership
author: nicholaswatt

text: My ex Tory whip adds note of caution: suspicious about the profusion of support from cabinet ministers for Theresa May on twitter. All a bit OTT
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Veteran Tory ex whip tells me: a few weeks ago Theresa May would have won confidence vote by two to one. Now it will be much closer. Source predicts PM will win but by narrower margin

@theresa_may @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Brady: rules of confidence vote designed to make it difficult to trigger process
author: nicholaswatt

text: Brady: aim to complete parliamentary stage of leadership contest before Christmas recess. First ballot next Tuesday. Postal ballot of party membership should be completed expeditiously
author: nicholaswatt

text: Brady: If Theresa May loses we will move rapidly to set rules for leadership contest. 1922 executive would meet tomorrow to set framework then party would have to approve decisions
author: nicholaswatt

text: Questions on ballot paper: I have confidence in Theresa May as leader of the Conservative party / I do not have confidence in Theresa May as leader of the Conservative party
author: nicholaswatt

text: Brady: I will announce result first at 9.00pm tonight and then read out numbers. Count to be conducted by me, Charles Walker and Dame Cheryl Gillan. Verification by 1922 committee
author: nicholaswatt

text: Brady: I am seeking clarification from chief whip whether two suspended Conservative MPs, Charlie Elphicke and Andrew Griffiths, will have whip restored, giving them a vote. That would make 317 Tory MPs
author: nicholaswatt

text: Brady says collection of 48 letters not like a fund raising thermometer outside a hospital. Letters submitted and withdrawn, suggesting that process happened yesterday. Process has been fluid
author: nicholaswatt

text: Brady: I made announcement of confidence vote early this morning to ensure it was made before markets open
author: nicholaswatt

text: Sir Graham Brady: I spoke to PM around 9.30pm last night after threshold of letters met. PM was keen to hold vote quickly - in line with rules which say vote should be held promptly
author: nicholaswatt

text: Early argument from the Stop Boris campaign: even if he wins a Tory leadership contest do not assume he becomes PM. Has to command confidence of commons to survive. Dominic Grieve and others suggesting they will resign whip if he wins
author: nicholaswatt

text: Chief whip Julian Smith leaves No 10. Says nothing when I ask if PM fighting to win
author: nicholaswatt

text: Not a normal day if Tory chairman leaves No 10 at 11pm
author: nicholaswatt

text: Tory chairman Brandon Lewis leaves No 10
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Blog on Tory resentment of Irish power within EU. After centuries of troubled Anglo-Irish relations it is smaller of two islands which appears to be exercising greater power for first time https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-46528952 …

@BBCNewsnight @theresa_may
author: nicholaswatt

text:
My interview with Nigel Dodds explains why Jeremy Corbyn thinks tabling a no confidence motion in Theresa May would be pointless at the moment

@NigelDoddsDUP @theresa_may @jeremycorbyn
author: nicholaswatt

text: All rocking in 21st century Tory party. Senior MP tells me problem with #brexit vote down to whips office. The MP says: ‘The problem is Theresa May has turned the whips office into a girls’ finishing school.’ @BBCNewsnight @theresa_may
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Dennis Skinner, who made his name as the Beast of Bolsover taunting Margaret Thatcher, achieves soundbite of the day by throwing Thatcher language back at PM: you are F-R-I-T

@theresa_may @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Theresa May was looking towards chief whip Julian Smith during speaker’s intervention. His deputy, Christopher Pincher, sitting on step behind him threw dark look at the speaker
author: nicholaswatt

text: We were waiting for the speaker to intervene and there it is: he wants parliament to decide if #brexit vote should be deferred but govt free to act unilaterally
author: nicholaswatt

text: When Ken Clarke and John Redwood - nearly a dream ticket in 1997 - have equally glum faces you know a Tory PM is in trouble
author: nicholaswatt

text: The complete silence on Tory benches is ominous
author: nicholaswatt

text: Tory grandees discussing GNU with Labour grandees. ‘Not going to happen,’ my informant tells me 2/2
author: nicholaswatt

text: There is a new beast being discussed by the big beasts of Westminster: GNU or Government of National Unity 1/2
author: nicholaswatt

text: Tory grandee again: what a disaster. PM can’t got to Brussels saying I might be sunk. She needs to show she has been sunk in Parliament 2/2
author: nicholaswatt

text: Tory grandee: this makes Dunkirk look like a sensible operation 1/2
author: nicholaswatt

text: DUP source says U-turn from Theresa May raises such questions about PM’s credibility they do not believe she will be able to secure meaningful concessions from EU. Best hope = changes to political declaration but that would not be legally binding 2/2
author: nicholaswatt

text: DUP source deeply unimpressed by delay of #brexit vote. Says: how on earth can we ever believe another word Theresa May says? She told us this vote would definitely happen and now she pulls it under pressure from cabinet 1/2
author: nicholaswatt

text:
Here is @BBCNews report on my interview with Sir Graham Brady https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-46472824 …

@BBCNewsnight @theresa_may @lizrawlings
author: nicholaswatt

text: Ace photographer @lizrawlings in action as I interview Sir Graham Brady filmed by great Keith Morris @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt

text: Finally from Sir Graham: If it can’t then I certainly would welcome the vote being deferred until such time as we can answer that question.
author: nicholaswatt

text: And more from Sir Graham: It’s having the answer to that question of substance that is most important, not the timing. So, if that question can be answered in the course of the next few days then all well and good....
author: nicholaswatt

text: Sir Graham Brady, chairman of 1922 committee, told me: I think the most important thing is to have clarity about how we might remove ourselves from a backstop, Northern Ireland protocol situation if we were to enter into one in the future....
author: nicholaswatt

text: Breaking: Sir Graham Brady tells me he would welcome the deferral by Theresa May of her #brexit meaningful vote unless she can provide clarity in coming days on how UK could leave the Northern Ireland backstop. Full interview on @BBCNewsnight
author: nicholaswatt
